metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
PEARL HARBOR, HAWAII
BOX 166, NAVY YARD
December 21, 1942
Dear Gertie,
Merry Christmas or at least as merry a on as is possible with all
of us separated as we are. I was reading Life last night and came across
that big full-page advertisement of Four Roses that has the eggnog receipe
that was always used on Christmas morning. I remember the fun we always had
beating up the eggs and arguing whether we shouldn't double the amount of
whiskey called for. After all this darn war can't last forever, and one of 
these days we will all be back together again.
Thank you ever so much for your letter of November 17, congratulating
me being a "proud father". I acknowledge that I am a father but I don't 
know about the proudness part of it. I always seem to reckon the whole
thing had been done occasionally by other people in the past, and that it
is really nothing very new. Sidney and I think having a baby must have
driven Nancy nuts for she is sending [me] all kinds of strange things. One
day I received a hank of red hair which she must have pulled from the poor
kids head; shortly afterwards she sent me a photograph of the baby's foot-
prints. Can you imagine me framing them and keeping them on my desk? If 
the war hasn't done anything else, it will at least save me from having
to get up in the middle of the night to rock the crib.
Sidney misses you terribly but otherwise is fit as a fiddle and is
very interested in what he's doing. He plays tennis often at lunch time
with a boy by the name of Teddy Burwell. He used to be rated about 14th
in the United States, and when he was in Oxford, spent all of his time 
traveling over Europe playing in tournaments. He is really darn good, and
he and Sidney have some marvelous games. This old man has had to give up
tennis since my series of bad colds. They seem to have run me down quite a 
bit with the result that my heart pounds with the slightest bit of exercise.
Our job isn't very exciting but at least there is always so much going
on that you never have time to think whether it is dull or not. Sidney and
I are supposed to be the executive officers of the Intelligence 6enter,
Pacific Ocean Areas. What executive officer means we have still to find out.
I am beginning to think it means trying to get things that other people are
too lazy to get for themselves. The Center is broken up into a variety of
sections such as Air Intelligence Section, Radio Section, Photographic Section,
Weather Section, Objective Data Section, etc. Some of the sections have
several hundres men, others are smaller. This, of course, is supposed to be
secret, but I am writing to the most secret of secret persons of Strategic
Service so I suppose there couldn't be any objection in telling you. When we
started, we found no office at all, then we had a little office in a basei-
ment, after a month moving to great big new offices especially arranged for us.
[End Page 1]
By now we have grown out of that and are just starting on a new two story
building for our exclusive use. This building is going to be right next to
the CINCPAC building. In case you don't know, CINCPAC stands for Commander
in Chief, Pacific Fleet. In view of the fact that he has specifically asked
for us to be moved up right next to him must mean that they think the
Intelligence Center is doing a good job. This is especially gratifying in
view of the fact that when we all first came out here, no one wanted
"hide nor hair" of us. And the common question seemed to be, "Why the hell
another Intelligence organization?"
We have been in our new apartment about a month and one half now. We
have more privacy and perhaps more space than we had at the Halekulani Hotel,
but I really don't like it quite as much because it is so far from the water,
and the hotel had lovely trees, flowers, and grass which we don't have now.
I hope that some day we will be able to find a little house right on the
water. We really haven't seen anybody since we have been out here for we
are just too darn tired to talk after the work at the office is finished.
I think I have dined out exactly twice in the 3[half] months. One of the times
with Lester Armour and once with Jack Merrill's [mother.] We usually leave the
office about half past 5, get home about 6. Sidney then goes for a short
swim while I experiment with the pots and pans. We both are in bed by 7
read and suffer with indigestion till about 10; then sleep until 6. It is
certainly not a very exciting life.
Merry Christmas again!
Lots of Love,
Morris
[End Page 2]
